flagÂ¶

Flag emoji for Python.

Converts flag emoji to ASCII and other way round.

Source on Github

This is based on http://schinckel.net/2015/10/29/unicode-flags-in-python/ by schinckel

ExampleÂ¶

>>> import flag

>>> flag.flagize("Flag of Israel :IL:")
'Flag of Israel ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡±'

>>> flag.dflagize(u"Flag of Israel ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡±")
'Flag of Israel :IL:'

>>> flag.flagize("England :gb-eng: is part of the UK :GB:", subregions=True)
'England ğŸ´ó §ó ¢ó ¥ó ®ó §ó ¿ is part of the UK ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§'

>>> flag.dflagize(u"England ğŸ´ó §ó ¢ó ¥ó ®ó §ó ¿ is part of the UK ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§", subregions=True)
'England :gb-eng: is part of the UK :GB:'

InstallÂ¶

pip install emoji-country-flag

See: https://pypi.org/project/emoji-country-flag/

How it worksÂ¶

All the flag emoji are actually composed of two unicode letters. These are the 26 regional indicator symbols.

Alone they look like this: ğŸ‡¦ ğŸ‡§ ğŸ‡¨ ğŸ‡© ğŸ‡ª ğŸ‡« ğŸ‡¬ ğŸ‡­ ğŸ‡® ğŸ‡¯ ğŸ‡° ğŸ‡± ğŸ‡² ğŸ‡³ ğŸ‡´ ğŸ‡µ ğŸ‡¶ ğŸ‡· ğŸ‡¸ ğŸ‡¹ ğŸ‡º ğŸ‡» ğŸ‡¼ ğŸ‡½ ğŸ‡¾ ğŸ‡¿

If you pair them up according to ISO 3166 some browsers and phones will display a flag. For example CZ is Czechia: ğŸ‡¨ + ğŸ‡¿ = ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¿

So, to encode an ASCII code like :NR: to ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡·, we just need to convert the ASCII N and R to the corresponding regional indicator symbols ğŸ‡³ and ğŸ‡·. To reverse it, we translate the regional indicator symbols back to ASCII letters.

How do subregional flags work?

FunctionsÂ¶

flag.flagize(text, subregions=False)[source]Â¶

Encode flags. Replace all two letter codes :XX: with unicode flags (emoji flag sequences)

Parameters

  • text (str) â€“ The text

  • subregions (bool) â€“ Also replace subregional/subdivision codes :xx-xxx: with unicode flags (flag emoji tag sequences).

Returns

The text with all occurrences of :XX: replaced by unicode flags

Return type

str

flag.dflagize(text, subregions=False)[source]Â¶

Decode flags. Replace all unicode country flags (emoji flag sequences) in text with ascii two letter code :XX:

Parameters

  • text (str) â€“ The text

  • subregions (bool) â€“ Also replace subregional/subdivision flags (flag emoji tag sequences) with :xx-xxx:

Returns

The text with all unicode flags replaced by ascii sequence :XX:

Return type

str

flag.flagize_subregional(text)[source]Â¶

Encode subregional/subdivision flags. Replace all regional codes :xx-xxx: with unicode flags (flag emoji tag sequences)

Parameters

text (str) â€“ The text

Returns

The text with all occurrences of :xx-xxx: replaced by unicode flags

Return type

str

flag.dflagize_subregional(text)[source]Â¶

Decode subregional/subdivision flags. Replace all unicode regional flags (flag emoji tag sequences) in text with their ascii code :xx-xxx:

Parameters

text (str) â€“ The text

Returns

The text with all regional flags replaced by ascii sequence :xx-xxx:

Return type

str

Subregional flagsÂ¶

The only widely supported subregional flags are currently: England, Scotland and Wales (as of iOS 12 and Android 9).

Code

Emoji

:gb-sct:

ğŸ´ó §ó ¢ó ³ó £ó ´ó ¿

:gb-wls:

ğŸ´ó §ó ¢ó ·ó ¬ó ³ó ¿

:gb-eng:

ğŸ´ó §ó ¢ó ¥ó ®ó §ó ¿

:us-tx:

ğŸ´ó µó ³ó ´ó ¸ó ¿
WhatsApp offers one other state flag: Texas.
If you use WhatsAppâ€™s emoji panel to select the Texas flag, WhatsApp uses ğŸ‡½ğŸ‡¹ i.e. flagize(â€œ:XT:â€) for Texas. This code â€œXTâ€ is specified by Unicode as â€œexcludedâ€ meaning it is explicitly for private use and can be defined by anyone. Therefore, it is likely not displayed as the Texas flag on other platforms.
But WhatsApp also recognizes the flag emoji tag sequence flagize(â€œ:us-tx:â€, subregions=True) and displays the same flag.

How subregional flags workÂ¶

They work very similar to the country flags. The ASCII codes are transformed by replacing them with specific codepoints that are called â€œtagsâ€.

The basic format for a tag flag is:
black_flag_emoji followed by region_code_in_tag followed by cancel_tag

Note

black_flag_emoji

U+1F3F4 ( ğŸ´ )

cancel_tag

U+E007F (invisible, signifies the end of the flag code)

region_code_in_tag

It is formed using the abbreviation defined in ISO 3166-2 and adding 0xE0000 to every ASCII value of the code. For example England is GB-ENG.

A full list of valid codes can be found here: github.com/unicode-org/â€¦/subdivisions/en.xml

Itâ€™s also possible to use a 3-digit-code from github.com/unicode-org/â€¦/UnMacroRegions.txt

Example:Â¶

England is GB-ENG in ISO 3166-2.
We drop the hyphen and make it lowercase to get gbeng.
To transform this to â€œtagsâ€, we need to add the value 0xE0000 = 917504 to every unicode value of gbeng:
g is unicode 0x67 or decimal 103, so 103 + 917504 = 917607 or 0xE0067
b is 0x62 and becomes 0xE0062
e is 0x65 and becomes 0xE0065
n is 0x6E and becomes 0xE006E
g is 0x67 and becomes 0xE0067

Together itâ€™s:

                      g        b        e        n        g
ASCII:                0x67     0x62     0x65     0x6E     0x67
Tags:   0x1F3F4    0xE0067  0xE0062  0xE0065  0xE006E  0xE0067  0xE007F
        black_flag                                             cancel_tag

Unlike the regional indicator symbols, tags are not rendered on incompatible system, they will simply be invisible and have no width. So, if the particular flag is not supported or if tag flags are not supported at all, the only visible character will be a black flag.

Hint

If you donâ€™t see the flags in your browser, try with your phone

https://flag.readthedocs.org
